results.title: The Secret Discovery of Australia (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This film reveals evidence which clearly shows that the Portuguese were on Australian soil long before either the Dutch or the English - in fact 250 years before Captain Cook. It is a story of spies and political espionage, resulting from the mantle of secrecy the Portuguese threw around their explorations and discoveries, and the efforts of their European counterparts to steal their maps.

results.title: The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole
results.brief_description: Based on the best-selling book by Sue Townsend, “The Secret Diary of Adrian Mole”, aged 13 3/4 years, is a funny, bitter-sweet comedy that will bring back those painful but amusing memories of growing up. Stars Julie Walters. Rated: PG

results.title: The Secret country: the first Australians fight back (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Central Independent Television (UK) and Alan Lowery
results.brief_description: According to John Pilger, “Australia is a secret country with a secret history.” This documentary looks at that history, the history of the Australian Aborigines from the time of white settlement to the present, and reveals the extent of the cruelty and injustice inflicted upon them. The central issue throughout the film is the differing perspective’s on the land and its uses, providing historical background to the present land rights movement and other areas of Aboriginal activism.

results.title: The Secret adventures of Tom Thumb
results.creator_credit: Bolexbrothers, Richard Hutchinson, Colin Rose, Thierry Garrel and Hengemeth Panahi
results.brief_description: This post-industrial version of the famous fariytale is given a Kafkaesque feel. Employing pixillation techniques which combine human, model and plasticine forms, the directors create a unique visual style. Leading a bleak existence in a nightmare city, a poor childless couple is suddenly and bloodily blessed with a tiny boy. their joy is short-lived for the Ministry of Sinistry agents kidnap Tom and whisk him off to the laboratory of a thousand terrors, a centre of terrifying and sadistic experiments. In this netherworld of pain, Tom finds himself among bizarre creatures, part fur, feather, bane and flesh. To escape is fraught with danger, but to stay is fatal. Technically flawless in the evocation of its grim and apocalyptic world, this film fuses its many influences, from the Quay Brothers and Svankmajer, to the short films of Starewicz, into a superbly integrated and coherent vision of evil and innocence. WARNING: Not suitable for children as some scenes may disturb some viewers.

results.title: The Secret'st man [b&w]
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, John Barnes and Douglas Campbell
results.brief_description: Part 3 of the series “Macbeth: a director’s interpretation”. This episode analyses the character of Macbeth to indicate that within every human being is a terrible lust for violence. It emphasises the capacity for good and evil within the same human heart portraying a sense of tragic loss in the character of Macbeth. We cannot hate him for there remains something sublime in him. Narrated by Douglas Campbell. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Secondary Teacher
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and E.J. Perry
results.brief_description: Describes the life of secondary student teachers in training: accommodation in a boarding house in Armadale, Victoria, for those from the country areas; Melbourne University and the various courses available for students. Also gives details about specialised couses and shows classes in progress. Shows the science, commerce, music and engineering faculties. Narrated by Terry Dear and animation by the Owen Brothers.

results.title: The Second law of thermodynamics (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Millbank Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Laws of Disorder Series”.
Discusses and illustrates the second law of thermodynamics which states that every system which is left to itself will, on the average, change towards a position of maximum probability. Professor Sir George Porter is the lecturer and author of the series.
